CreditLine: Museum purchase [formerly part of the Walters Collection], 1942
Description: Amulets are often worn on the body or hung in architectural spaces. Their purpose is to protect against ailments and other types of danger and to encourage success and fortitude. This 18th-century Iranian example is covered with micrographic writing, including verses from the Qur'an and the 99 Beautiful Names (al-asma al-husna) of God, which describe his divine attributes. Qur'anic verses are considered by some believers to have protective powers.

Exhibitions.ExhTitle: Poetry and Prayer: Islamic Manuscripts from the Walters Art Museum
Exhibitions.Textblock: Poetry and Prayer: Islamic Manuscripts from the Walters Art Museum. The Walters Art Museum, Baltimore. 2010.

Inscriptions: [Date] A.H. Rajab 1161; [Translation] ...Oh God, truly God is all- powerful in all things...

MuseumLocation.DisplayCurrentLocation: Centre Street: Third Floor: Islamic Art

Provenance: Henry Walters, New York, [date of acquisition unknown] by purchase; Sadie Jones (Mrs. Henry Walters), New York, 1931, by inheritance; Joseph Brummer, New York, [date of acquisition unknown] by purchase; Walters Art Museum, 1942, by purchase.
Title: Talisman
